faq.question: How much of a caloric deficit is too much?
faq.answer: Don't go below 1200 calories (women) or 1500 calories (men) without medical supervision. Deficits larger than 1000 calories/day can trigger metabolic adaptation and muscle loss.

faq.question: Why am I not losing weight in a deficit?
faq.answer: Common reasons include underestimating food intake, overestimating exercise calories, water retention, or metabolic adaptation. Track accurately for 2-3 weeks before adjusting.

faq.question: Should I eat back exercise calories?
faq.answer: If you're at a moderate deficit (500 cal), eating back half your exercise calories prevents excessive restriction. Listen to your hunger signals.

faq.question: How do I break a weight loss plateau?
faq.answer: Try recalculating TDEE at your new weight, take a diet break at maintenance, increase protein, change your exercise routine, or slightly adjust your deficit.

faq.question: Is it better to cut carbs or fat?
faq.answer: For weight loss, total calories matter most. Keep protein high (0.7-1g per pound), then adjust carbs and fats based on preference and energy needs.

faq.question: How accurate is the TDEE calculation?
faq.answer: TDEE formulas estimate within 10-15% for most people. Use it as a starting point, then adjust based on real-world results over 2-4 weeks.
